# ASCII

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

Not to be confused with MS [Windows-1252](/wiki/Windows-1252 "Windows-1252")
or other types of [extended ASCII](/wiki/Extended_ASCII "Extended ASCII").

This article is about the character encoding. For other uses, see [ASCII
(disambiguation)](/wiki/ASCII_\(disambiguation\) "ASCII \(disambiguation\)").

**ASCII** ([/ˈæski/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") ([![About this
sound](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-
Loudspeaker.svg.png)](/wiki/File:En-us-ASCII.ogg "About this sound")
[listen](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3b/En-us-ASCII.ogg "En-us-
ASCII.ogg")) [_ASS -kee_](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key
"Help:Pronunciation respelling key")),[1]:6 abbreviated from **American
Standard Code for Information Interchange** , is a [character
encoding](/wiki/Character_encoding "Character encoding") standard for
electronic communication. ASCII codes represent text in computers,
[telecommunications equipment](/wiki/Telecommunications_equipment
"Telecommunications equipment"), and other devices. Most modern character-
encoding schemes are based on ASCII, although they support many additional
characters.

ASCII is the traditional name for the encoding system; the [Internet Assigned
Numbers Authority](/wiki/Internet_Assigned_Numbers_Authority "Internet
Assigned Numbers Authority") (IANA) prefers the updated name **US-ASCII** ,
which clarifies that this system was developed in the US and based on the
typographical symbols predominantly in use there.[2]

ASCII is one of a 1963 [List of IEEE milestones](/wiki/List_of_IEEE_milestones
"List of IEEE milestones").

ASCII chart from an earlier-than 1972 printer manual (b1 is the least

## Overview[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ASCII&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Overview")]

ASCII was developed from [telegraph code](/wiki/Telegraph_code "Telegraph
code"). Its first commercial use was as a seven-[bit](/wiki/Bit "Bit")
[teleprinter](/wiki/Teleprinter "Teleprinter") code promoted by Bell data
services. Work on the ASCII standard began on October 6, 1960, with the first
meeting of the [American Standards
Association](/wiki/American_Standards_Association "American Standards
Association")'s (ASA) (now the [American National Standards
Institute](/wiki/American_National_Standards_Institute "American National
Standards Institute") or ANSI) X3.2 subcommittee. The first edition of the
standard was published in 1963,[3][4] underwent a major revision during
1967,[5][6] and experienced its most recent update during 1986.[7] Compared to
earlier telegraph codes, the proposed Bell code and ASCII were both ordered
for more convenient sorting (i.e., alphabetization) of lists, and added
features for devices other than teleprinters.

Originally based on the [English alphabet](/wiki/English_alphabet "English
alphabet"), ASCII encodes 128 specified
[characters](/wiki/Character_\(computing\) "Character \(computing\)") into
seven-bit integers as shown by the ASCII chart above.[8] Ninety-five of the
encoded characters are printable: these include the digits _0_ to _9_ ,
lowercase letters _a_ to _z_ , uppercase letters _A_ to _Z_ , and [punctuation
symbols](/wiki/Punctuation_symbol "Punctuation symbol"). In addition, the
original ASCII specification included 33 non-printing [control
codes](/wiki/Control_code "Control code") which originated with [Teletype
machines](/wiki/Teletype_machine "Teletype machine"); most of these are now
obsolete.[9]

For example, lowercase _[i](/wiki/I "I")_ would be represented in the ASCII
encoding by [binary](/wiki/Binary_number "Binary number") 1101001 =
[hexadecimal](/wiki/Hexadecimal "Hexadecimal") 69 (_i_ is the ninth letter) =
[decimal](/wiki/Decimal "Decimal") 105\.

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ASCII&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: History")]

The American Standard Code for Information Interchange (ASCII) was developed
under the auspices of a committee of the [American Standards
Association](/wiki/American_Standards_Association "American Standards
Association") (ASA), called the X3 committee, by its X3.2 (later X3L2)
subcommittee, and later by that subcommittee's X3.2.4 working group (now
[INCITS](/wiki/INCITS "INCITS")). The ASA became the [United States of America
Standards Institute](/wiki/United_States_of_America_Standards_Institute
"United States of America Standards Institute") (USASI)[1]:211 and ultimately
the [American National Standards
Institute](/wiki/American_National_Standards_Institute "American National
Standards Institute") (ANSI).

With the other special characters and control codes filled in, ASCII was
published as ASA X3.4-1963,[4][10] leaving 28 code positions without any
assigned meaning, reserved for future standardization, and one unassigned
control code.[1]:66, 245 There was some debate at the time whether there
should be more control characters rather than the lowercase alphabet.[1]:435
The indecision did not last long: during May 1963 the CCITT Working Party on
the New Telegraph Alphabet proposed to assign lowercase characters to
_sticks_[a][11] 6 and 7,[12] and [International Organization for
Standardization](/wiki/International_Organization_for_Standardization
"International Organization for Standardization") TC 97 SC 2 voted during
October to incorporate the change into its draft standard.[13] The X3.2.4 task
group voted its approval for the change to ASCII at its May 1963 meeting.[14]
Locating the lowercase letters in _sticks_[a][11] 6 and 7 caused the
characters to differ in bit pattern from the upper case by a single bit, which
simplified [case-insensitive](/wiki/Case-insensitive "Case-insensitive")
character matching and the construction of keyboards and printers.

The X3 committee made other changes, including other new characters (the
[brace](/wiki/Brace_\(punctuation\) "Brace \(punctuation\)") and [vertical
bar](/wiki/Vertical_bar "Vertical bar") characters),[15] renaming some control
characters (SOM became start of header (SOH)) and moving or removing others
(RU was removed).[1]:247–248 ASCII was subsequently updated as USAS
X3.4-1967,[5][16] then USAS X3.4-1968, ANSI X3.4-1977, and finally, ANSI
X3.4-1986.[7][17]

Revisions of the ASCII standard:

  * ASA X3.4-1963[1][4][16][17]
  * ASA X3.4-1965 (approved, but not published, nevertheless used by [IBM 2260](/wiki/IBM_2260 "IBM 2260") & [2265](/wiki/IBM_2265 "IBM 2265") Display Stations and [IBM 2848](/wiki/IBM_2848 "IBM 2848") Display Control)[1]:423, 425–428, 435–439[16][17]
  * USAS X3.4-1967[1][5][17]
  * USAS X3.4-1968[1][17]
  * ANSI X3.4-1977[17]
  * ANSI X3.4-1986[7][17]
  * ANSI X3.4-1986 (R1992)
  * ANSI X3.4-1986 (R1997)
  * ANSI INCITS 4-1986 (R2002)[18]
  * ANSI INCITS 4-1986 (R2007)[19]
  * ANSI INCITS 4-1986 (R2012)

In the X3.15 standard, the X3 committee also addressed how ASCII should be
transmitted ([least significant bit](/wiki/Least_significant_bit "Least
significant bit") first),[1]:249–253[20] and how it should be recorded on
perforated tape. They proposed a [9-track](/wiki/9-track "9-track") standard
for magnetic tape, and attempted to deal with some [punched
card](/wiki/Punched_card "Punched card") formats.

## Design considerations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ASCII&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Design considerations")]

### Bit width[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ASCII&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Bit width")]

The X3.2 subcommittee designed ASCII based on the earlier
[teleprinter](/wiki/Teleprinter "Teleprinter") encoding systems. Like other
[character encodings](/wiki/Character_encoding "Character encoding"), ASCII
specifies a correspondence between digital bit patterns and
[character](/wiki/Character_\(computing\) "Character \(computing\)") symbols
(i.e. [graphemes](/wiki/Grapheme "Grapheme") and [control
characters](/wiki/Control_character "Control character")). This allows
[digital](/wiki/Digital_data "Digital data") devices to communicate with each
other and to process, store, and communicate character-oriented information
such as written language. Before ASCII was developed, the encodings in use
included 26 [alphabetic](/wiki/English_alphabet "English alphabet")
characters, 10 [numerical digits](/wiki/Numerical_digit "Numerical digit"),
and from 11 to 25 special graphic symbols. To include all these, and control
characters compatible with the [Comité Consultatif International Téléphonique
et Télégraphique](/wiki/CCITT "CCITT") (CCITT) [International Telegraph
Alphabet No. 2](/wiki/International_Telegraph_Alphabet_No._2 "International
Telegraph Alphabet No. 2") (ITA2) standard of 1924,[21][22]
[FIELDATA](/wiki/FIELDATA "FIELDATA") (1956[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]), and
early [EBCDIC](/wiki/EBCDIC "EBCDIC") (1963), more than 64 codes were required
for ASCII.

ITA2 were in turn based on the 5-bit telegraph code [Émile
Baudot](/wiki/%C3%89mile_Baudot "Émile Baudot") invented in 1870 and patented
in 1874.[22]

The committee debated the possibility of a [shift](/wiki/Shift_code "Shift
code") function (like in [ITA2](/wiki/ITA2 "ITA2")), which would allow more
than 64 codes to be represented by a [six-bit code](/wiki/Six-
bit_character_code "Six-bit character code"). In a shifted code, some
character codes determine choices between options for the following character
codes. It allows compact encoding, but is less reliable for [data
transmission](/wiki/Data_transmission "Data transmission"), as an error in
transmitting the shift code typically makes a long part of the transmission
unreadable. The standards committee decided against shifting, and so ASCII
required at least a seven-bit code.[1]:215, 236 § 4

The committee considered an eight-bit code, since eight bits
([octets](/wiki/Octet_\(computing\) "Octet \(computing\)")) would allow two
four-bit patterns to efficiently encode two digits with [binary-coded
decimal](/wiki/Binary-coded_decimal "Binary-coded decimal"). However, it would
require all data transmission to send eight bits when seven could suffice. The
committee voted to use a seven-bit code to minimize costs associated with data
transmission. Since perforated tape at the time could record eight bits in one
position, it also allowed for a [parity bit](/wiki/Parity_bit "Parity bit")
for [error checking](/wiki/Error_checking "Error checking") if
desired.[1]:217, 236 § 5 [Eight-bit](/wiki/Eight-bit "Eight-bit") machines
(with octets as the native data type) that did not use parity checking
typically set the eighth bit to 0.[23] In some printers, the high bit was used
to enable [Italics](/wiki/Italics "Italics") printing.

### Internal
organization[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ASCII&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Internal organization")]

The code itself was patterned so that most control codes were together and all
graphic codes were together, for ease of identification. The first two so
called _ASCII sticks_[a][11] (32 positions) were reserved for control
characters.[1]:220, 236 § 8,9) The ["space"
character](/wiki/Space_\(punctuation\) "Space \(punctuation\)") had to come
before graphics to make [sorting](/wiki/Sorting_algorithm "Sorting algorithm")
easier, so it became position 20[hex](/wiki/Hexadecimal "Hexadecimal");[1]:237
§ 10 for the same reason, many special signs commonly used as separators were
placed before digits. The committee decided it was important to support
[uppercase](/wiki/Upper_case "Upper case") [64-character
alphabets](/wiki/Sixbit_code_pages "Sixbit code pages"), and chose to pattern
ASCII so it could be reduced easily to a usable 64-character set of graphic
codes,[1]:228, 237 § 14 as was done in the [DEC SIXBIT](/wiki/DEC_SIXBIT "DEC
SIXBIT") code (1963). [Lowercase](/wiki/Lower_case "Lower case") letters were
therefore not interleaved with uppercase. To keep options available for
lowercase letters and other graphics, the special and numeric codes were
arranged before the letters, and the letter _A_ was placed in position
41[hex](/wiki/Hexadecimal "Hexadecimal") to match the draft of the
corresponding British standard.[1]:238 § 18 The digits 0–9 are prefixed with
011, but the remaining [4 bits](/wiki/Nibble "Nibble") correspond to their
respective values in binary, making conversion with [binary-coded
decimal](/wiki/Binary-coded_decimal "Binary-coded decimal") straightforward.

Many of the non-alphanumeric characters were positioned to correspond to their
shifted position on typewriters; an important subtlety is that these were
based on _mechanical_ typewriters, not _electric_ typewriters.[24] Mechanical
typewriters followed the standard set by the Remington No. 2 (1878), the first
typewriter with a shift key, and the shifted values of `23456789-` were
`"#$%_&'()` – early typewriters omitted _0_ and _1_ , using _O_ (capital
letter _o_) and _l_ (lowercase letter _L_) instead, but `1!` and `0)` pairs
became standard once 0 and 1 became common. Thus, in ASCII `!"#$%` were placed
in the second stick,[a][11] positions 1–5, corresponding to the digits 1–5 in
the adjacent stick.[a][11] The parentheses could not correspond to _9_ and _0_
, however, because the place corresponding to _0_ was taken by the space
character. This was accommodated by removing `_` (underscore) from _6_ and
shifting the remaining characters, which corresponded to many European
typewriters that placed the parentheses with _8_ and _9_. This discrepancy
from typewriters led to [bit-paired keyboards](/wiki/Bit-paired_keyboard "Bit-
paired keyboard"), notably the [Teletype Model 33](/wiki/Teletype_Model_33
"Teletype Model 33"), which used the left-shifted layout corresponding to
ASCII, not to traditional mechanical typewriters. Electric typewriters,
notably the [IBM Selectric](/wiki/IBM_Selectric "IBM Selectric") (1961), used
a somewhat different layout that has become standard on computers – following
the [IBM PC](/wiki/IBM_PC "IBM PC") (1981), especially [Model M](/wiki/Model_M
"Model M") (1984) – and thus shift values for symbols on modern keyboards do
not correspond as closely to the ASCII table as earlier keyboards did. The
`/?` pair also dates to the No. 2, and the `,< .>` pairs were used on some
keyboards (others, including the No. 2, did not shift `,` (comma) or `.` (full
stop) so they could be used in uppercase without unshifting). However, ASCII
split the `;:` pair (dating to No. 2), and rearranged mathematical symbols
(varied conventions, commonly `-* =+`) to `:* ;+ -=`.

Some common characters were not included, notably `½¼¢`, while `^`~` were
included as diacritics for international use, and `<>` for mathematical use,
together with the simple line characters `\|` (in addition to common `/`). The
_@_ symbol was not used in continental Europe and the committee expected it
would be replaced by an accented _À_ in the French variation, so the _@_ was
placed in position 40[hex](/wiki/Hexadecimal "Hexadecimal"), right before the
letter A.[1]:243

The control codes felt essential for data transmission were the start of
message (SOM), end of address (EOA), [end of message](/wiki/End_of_Message
"End of Message") (EOM), end of transmission (EOT), "who are you?" (WRU), "are
you?" (RU), a reserved device control (DC0), synchronous idle (SYNC), and
acknowledge (ACK). These were positioned to maximize the [Hamming
distance](/wiki/Hamming_distance "Hamming distance") between their bit
patterns.[1]:243–245

### Character order[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ASCII&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Character order")]

ASCII-code order is also called _ASCIIbetical_ order.[25]
[Collation](/wiki/Collation "Collation") of data is sometimes done in this
order rather than "standard" alphabetical order ([collating
sequence](/wiki/Collating_sequence "Collating sequence")). The main deviations
in ASCII order are:

  * All uppercase come before lowercase letters; for example, "Z" precedes "a"
  * Digits and many punctuation marks come before letters

An intermediate order converts uppercase letters to lowercase before comparing
ASCII values.

## Character groups[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ASCII&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Character groups")]

### Control characters[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ASCII&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Control characters")]

Main article: [Control character](/wiki/Control_character "Control character")

ASCII reserves the first 32 codes (numbers 0–31 decimal) for [control
characters](/wiki/Control_character "Control character"): codes originally
intended not to represent printable information, but rather to control devices
(such as [printers](/wiki/Computer_printer "Computer printer")) that make use
of ASCII, or to provide [meta-information](/wiki/Metadata "Metadata") about
data streams such as those stored on magnetic tape.

For example, character 10 represents the "line feed" function (which causes a
printer to advance its paper), and character 8 represents "backspace".
[RFC](/wiki/Request_for_Comments_\(identifier\) "Request for Comments
\(identifier\)") [2822](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2822) refers to control
characters that do not include carriage return, line feed or [white
space](/wiki/Whitespace_\(computer_science\) "Whitespace \(computer
science\)") as non-whitespace control characters.[26] Except for the control
characters that prescribe elementary line-oriented formatting, ASCII does not
define any mechanism for describing the structure or appearance of text within
a document. Other schemes, such as [markup languages](/wiki/Markup_language
"Markup language"), address page and document layout and formatting.

The original ASCII standard used only short descriptive phrases for each
control character. The ambiguity this caused was sometimes intentional, for
example where a character would be used slightly differently on a terminal
link than on a [data stream](/wiki/Data_stream "Data stream"), and sometimes
accidental, for example with the meaning of "delete".

Probably the most influential single device on the interpretation of these
characters was the [Teletype Model 33](/wiki/Teletype_Model_33 "Teletype Model
33") ASR, which was a printing terminal with an available [paper
tape](/wiki/Punched_tape "Punched tape") reader/punch option. Paper tape was a
very popular medium for long-term program storage until the 1980s, less costly
and in some ways less fragile than magnetic tape. In particular, the Teletype
Model 33 machine assignments for codes 17 (Control-Q, DC1, also known as XON),
19 (Control-S, DC3, also known as XOFF), and 127 ([Delete](/wiki/Delete_key
"Delete key")) became de facto standards. The Model 33 was also notable for
taking the description of Control-G (code 7, BEL, meaning audibly alert the
operator) literally, as the unit contained an actual bell which it rang when
it received a BEL character. Because the keytop for the O key also showed a
left-arrow symbol (from ASCII-1963, which had this character instead of
[underscore](/wiki/Underscore "Underscore")), a noncompliant use of code 15
(Control-O, Shift In) interpreted as "delete previous character" was also
adopted by many early timesharing systems but eventually became neglected.

When a Teletype 33 ASR equipped with the automatic paper tape reader received
a Control-S (XOFF, an abbreviation for transmit off), it caused the tape
reader to stop; receiving Control-Q (XON, "transmit on") caused the tape
reader to resume. This technique became adopted by several early computer
operating systems as a "handshaking" signal warning a sender to stop
transmission because of impending overflow; it persists to this day in many
systems as a manual output control technique. On some systems Control-S
retains its meaning but Control-Q is replaced by a second Control-S to resume
output. The 33 ASR also could be configured to employ Control-R (DC2) and
Control-T (DC4) to start and stop the tape punch; on some units equipped with
this function, the corresponding control character lettering on the keycap
above the letter was TAPE and ~~TAPE~~ respectively.[27]

The Teletype could not move the head backwards, so it did not put a key on the
keyboard to send a BS (backspace). Instead there was a key marked "rubout"
that sent code 127 (DEL). The purpose of this key was to erase mistakes in a
hand-typed paper tape: the operator had to push a button on the tape punch to
back it up, then type the rubout, which punched all holes and replaced the
mistake with a character that was intended to be ignored.[28] Teletypes were
commonly used for the less-expensive computers from [Digital Equipment
Corporation](/wiki/Digital_Equipment_Corporation "Digital Equipment
Corporation"), so these systems had to use the available key and thus the DEL
code to erase the previous character.[29][30] Because of this, DEC video
terminals (by default) sent the DEL code for the key marked "Backspace" while
the key marked "Delete" sent an escape sequence, while many other terminals
sent BS for the Backspace key. The Unix terminal driver could only use one
code to back up, this could be set to BS _or_ DEL, but not both, resulting in
a very long period of annoyance where you had to correct it depending on what
terminal you were using (modern shells using [readline](/wiki/Readline
"Readline") understand both codes). The assumption that no key sent a BS
caused Control+H to be used for other purposes, such as a "help" command in
Emacs.[31]

Many more of the control codes have been given meanings quite different from
their original ones. The "escape" character (ESC, code 27), for example, was
intended originally to allow sending other control characters as literals
instead of invoking their meaning. This is the same meaning of "escape"
encountered in URL encodings, [C language](/wiki/C_\(programming_language\) "C
\(programming language\)") strings, and other systems where certain characters
have a reserved meaning. Over time this meaning has been co-opted and has
eventually been changed. In modern use, an ESC sent to the terminal usually
indicates the start of a command sequence usually in the form of a so-called
"[ANSI escape code](/wiki/ANSI_escape_code "ANSI escape code")" (or, more
properly, a "[Control Sequence Introducer](/wiki/Control_Sequence_Introducer
"Control Sequence Introducer")") from ECMA-48 (1972) and its successors,
beginning with ESC followed by a "[" (left-bracket) character. An ESC sent
from the terminal is most often used as an [out-of-band](/wiki/Out-of-
band_data "Out-of-band data") character used to terminate an operation, as in
the [TECO](/wiki/Text_Editor_and_Corrector "Text Editor and Corrector") and
[vi](/wiki/Vi "Vi") [text editors](/wiki/Text_editor "Text editor"). In
[graphical user interface](/wiki/Graphical_user_interface "Graphical user
interface") (GUI) and [windowing](/wiki/Window_\(computing\) "Window
\(computing\)") systems, ESC generally causes an application to abort its
current operation or to [exit](/wiki/Exit_\(operating_system\) "Exit
\(operating system\)") (terminate) altogether.

The inherent ambiguity of many control characters, combined with their
historical usage, created problems when transferring "plain text" files
between systems. The best example of this is the [newline](/wiki/Newline
"Newline") problem on various [operating systems](/wiki/Operating_system
"Operating system"). Teletype machines required that a line of text be
terminated with both "Carriage Return" (which moves the printhead to the
beginning of the line) and "Line Feed" (which advances the paper one line
without moving the printhead). The name "Carriage Return" comes from the fact
that on a manual [typewriter](/wiki/Typewriter "Typewriter") the carriage
holding the paper moved while the position where the typebars struck the
ribbon remained stationary. The entire carriage had to be pushed (returned) to
the right in order to position the left margin of the paper for the next line.

[DEC](/wiki/Digital_Equipment_Corporation "Digital Equipment Corporation")
operating systems ([OS/8](/wiki/OS/8 "OS/8"), [RT-11](/wiki/RT-11 "RT-11"),
[RSX-11](/wiki/RSX-11 "RSX-11"), [RSTS](/wiki/RSTS/E "RSTS/E"),
[TOPS-10](/wiki/TOPS-10 "TOPS-10"), etc.) used both characters to mark the end
of a line so that the console device (originally [Teletype
machines](/wiki/Teleprinter "Teleprinter")) would work. By the time so-called
"glass TTYs" (later called CRTs or terminals) came along, the convention was
so well established that backward compatibility necessitated continuing the
convention. When [Gary Kildall](/wiki/Gary_Kildall "Gary Kildall") created
[CP/M](/wiki/CP/M "CP/M") he was inspired by some command line interface
conventions used in [DEC](/wiki/Digital_Equipment_Corporation "Digital
Equipment Corporation")'s [RT-11](/wiki/RT-11 "RT-11"). Until the introduction
of [PC DOS](/wiki/PC_DOS "PC DOS") in 1981, [IBM](/wiki/IBM "IBM") had no hand
in this because their 1970s operating systems used EBCDIC instead of ASCII and
they were oriented toward punch-card input and line printer output on which
the concept of carriage return was meaningless. IBM's [PC DOS](/wiki/PC_DOS
"PC DOS") (also marketed as [MS-DOS](/wiki/MS-DOS "MS-DOS") by Microsoft)
inherited the convention by virtue of being loosely based on [CP/M](/wiki/CP/M
"CP/M"),[32] and [Windows](/wiki/Windows "Windows") inherited it from MS-DOS.

Unfortunately, requiring two characters to mark the end of a line introduces
unnecessary complexity and questions as to how to interpret each character
when encountered alone. To simplify matters [plain text](/wiki/Plain_text
"Plain text") data streams, including files, on [Multics](/wiki/Multics
"Multics")[33] used line feed (LF) alone as a line terminator.
[Unix](/wiki/Unix "Unix") and [Unix-like](/wiki/Unix-like "Unix-like")
systems, and [Amiga](/wiki/Amiga "Amiga") systems, adopted this convention
from Multics. The original [Macintosh OS](/wiki/Macintosh_OS "Macintosh OS"),
[Apple DOS](/wiki/Apple_DOS "Apple DOS"), and [ProDOS](/wiki/ProDOS "ProDOS"),
on the other hand, used carriage return (CR) alone as a line terminator;
however, since Apple replaced these operating systems with the Unix-based
[macOS](/wiki/MacOS "MacOS") operating system, they now use line feed (LF) as
well. The Radio Shack [TRS-80](/wiki/TRS-80 "TRS-80") also used a lone CR to
terminate lines.

Computers attached to the [ARPANET](/wiki/ARPANET "ARPANET") included machines
running operating systems such as TOPS-10 and [TENEX](/wiki/TOPS-20#TENEX
"TOPS-20") using CR-LF line endings, machines running operating systems such
as Multics using LF line endings, and machines running operating systems such
as [OS/360](/wiki/OS/360 "OS/360") that represented lines as a character count
followed by the characters of the line and that used [EBCDIC](/wiki/EBCDIC
"EBCDIC") rather than ASCII. The [Telnet](/wiki/Telnet "Telnet") protocol
defined an ASCII "[Network Virtual
Terminal](/w/index.php?title=Network_Virtual_Terminal&action=edit&redlink=1
"Network Virtual Terminal \(page does not exist\)")" (NVT), so that
connections between hosts with different line-ending conventions and character
sets could be supported by transmitting a standard text format over the
network. Telnet used ASCII along with CR-LF line endings, and software using
other conventions would translate between the local conventions and the
NVT.[34] The [File Transfer Protocol](/wiki/File_Transfer_Protocol "File
Transfer Protocol") adopted the Telnet protocol, including use of the Network
Virtual Terminal, for use when transmitting commands and transferring data in
the default ASCII mode.[35][36] This adds complexity to implementations of
those protocols, and to other network protocols, such as those used for E-mail
and the World Wide Web, on systems not using the NVT's CR-LF line-ending
convention.[37][38]

The PDP-6 monitor,[29] and its PDP-10 successor TOPS-10,[30] used Control-Z
(SUB) as an end-of-file indication for input from a terminal. Some operating
systems such as CP/M tracked file length only in units of disk blocks and used
Control-Z to mark the end of the actual text in the file.[39] For these
reasons, EOF, or [end-of-file](/wiki/End-of-file "End-of-file"), was used
colloquially and conventionally as a [three-letter acronym](/wiki/Three-
letter_acronym "Three-letter acronym") for Control-Z instead of SUBstitute.
The end-of-text code ([ETX](/wiki/End-of-text_character "End-of-text
character")), also known as [Control-C](/wiki/Control-C "Control-C"), was
inappropriate for a variety of reasons, while using Z as the control code to
end a file is analogous to it ending the alphabet and serves as a very
convenient [mnemonic aid](/wiki/Mnemonic_device "Mnemonic device"). A
historically common and still prevalent convention uses the ETX code
convention to interrupt and halt a program via an input data stream, usually
from a keyboard.

In C library and [Unix](/wiki/Unix "Unix") conventions, the [null
character](/wiki/Null_character "Null character") is used to terminate text
[strings](/wiki/String_\(computer_science\) "String \(computer science\)");
such [null-terminated strings](/wiki/Null-terminated_string "Null-terminated
string") can be known in abbreviation as ASCIZ or ASCIIZ, where here Z stands
for "zero".

### Printable characters[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ASCII&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Printable characters")]

Codes 20[hex](/wiki/Hexadecimal "Hexadecimal") to 7E[hex](/wiki/Hexadecimal
"Hexadecimal"), known as the printable characters, represent letters, digits,
[punctuation marks](/wiki/Punctuation_mark "Punctuation mark"), and a few
miscellaneous symbols. There are 95 printable characters in total.[m]

Code 20[hex](/wiki/Hexadecimal "Hexadecimal"), the ["space"
character](/wiki/Space_\(punctuation\) "Space \(punctuation\)"), denotes the
space between words, as produced by the space bar of a keyboard. Since the
space character is considered an invisible graphic (rather than a control
character)[1]:223[40] it is listed in the table below instead of in the
previous section.

Code 7F[hex](/wiki/Hexadecimal "Hexadecimal") corresponds to the non-printable
"delete" (DEL) control character and is therefore omitted from this chart; it
is covered in the previous section's chart. Earlier versions of ASCII used the
up arrow instead of the [caret](/wiki/Caret "Caret")
(5E[hex](/wiki/Hexadecimal "Hexadecimal")) and the left arrow instead of the
[underscore](/wiki/Underscore "Underscore") (5F[hex](/wiki/Hexadecimal
"Hexadecimal")).[4][41]

## Use[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ASCII&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section:
Use")]

ASCII was first used commercially during 1963 as a seven-bit teleprinter code
for [American Telephone & Telegraph](/wiki/American_Telephone_%26_Telegraph
"American Telephone & Telegraph")'s TWX (TeletypeWriter eXchange) network. TWX
originally used the earlier five-bit [ITA2](/wiki/ITA2 "ITA2"), which was also
used by the competing [Telex](/wiki/Telex "Telex") teleprinter system. [Bob
Bemer](/wiki/Robert_William_Bemer "Robert William Bemer") introduced features
such as the [escape sequence](/wiki/Escape_character "Escape character").[3]
His British colleague [Hugh McGregor Ross](/wiki/Hugh_McGregor_Ross "Hugh
McGregor Ross") helped to popularize this work – according to Bemer, "so much
so that the code that was to become ASCII was first called the _Bemer-Ross
Code_ in Europe".[42] Because of his extensive work on ASCII, Bemer has been
called "the father of ASCII".[43]

On March 11, 1968, U.S. President [Lyndon B. Johnson](/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson
"Lyndon B. Johnson") mandated that all computers purchased by the United
States federal government support ASCII, stating:[44][45][46]

> I have also approved recommendations of the [Secretary of
> Commerce](/wiki/Secretary_of_Commerce "Secretary of Commerce") regarding
> standards for recording the Standard Code for Information Interchange on
> magnetic tapes and paper tapes when they are used in computer operations.
> All computers and related equipment configurations brought into the [Federal
> Government](/wiki/Federal_Government "Federal Government") inventory on and
> after July 1, 1969, must have the capability to use the Standard Code for
> Information Interchange and the formats prescribed by the magnetic tape and
> paper tape standards when these media are used.

ASCII was the most common character encoding on the [World Wide
Web](/wiki/World_Wide_Web "World Wide Web") until December 2007, when
[UTF-8](/wiki/UTF-8 "UTF-8") encoding surpassed it; UTF-8 is backward
compatible with ASCII.[47][48][49]

## Variants and
derivations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ASCII&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Variants and derivations")]

As computer technology spread throughout the world, different [standards
bodies](/wiki/Standardization "Standardization") and corporations developed
many variations of ASCII to facilitate the expression of non-English languages
that used Roman-based alphabets. One could class some of these variations as
"[ASCII extensions](/wiki/ASCII_extension "ASCII extension")", although some
misuse that term to represent all variants, including those that do not
preserve ASCII's character-map in the 7-bit range. Furthermore, the ASCII
extensions have also been mislabelled as ASCII.

### 7-bit codes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ASCII&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: 7-bit codes")]

Main articles: [ECMA-6](/wiki/ECMA-6 "ECMA-6"), [ISO/IEC
646](/wiki/ISO/IEC_646 "ISO/IEC 646"), and [ITU T.50](/wiki/ITU_T.50 "ITU
T.50")

See also: [UTF-7](/wiki/UTF-7 "UTF-7")

From early in its development,[50] ASCII was intended to be just one of
several national variants of an international character code standard.

Other international standards bodies have ratified character encodings such as
[ISO 646](/wiki/ISO_646 "ISO 646") (1967) that are identical or nearly
identical to ASCII, with extensions for characters outside the English
[alphabet](/wiki/Alphabet "Alphabet") and symbols used outside the United
States, such as the symbol for the United Kingdom's [pound
sterling](/wiki/Pound_sterling "Pound sterling") (£). Almost every country
needed an adapted version of ASCII, since ASCII suited the needs of only the
US and a few other countries. For example, Canada had its own version that
supported French characters.

Many other countries developed variants of ASCII to include non-English
letters (e.g. [é](/wiki/%C3%89 "É"), [ñ](/wiki/%C3%91 "Ñ"), [ß](/wiki/%C3%9F
"ß"), [Ł](/wiki/%C5%81 "Ł")), currency symbols (e.g. [£](/wiki/%C2%A3 "£"),
[¥](/wiki/%C2%A5 "¥")), etc. See also [YUSCII](/wiki/YUSCII "YUSCII")
(Yugoslavia).

It would share most characters in common, but assign other locally useful
characters to several [code points](/wiki/Code_point "Code point") reserved
for "national use". However, the four years that elapsed between the
publication of ASCII-1963 and ISO's first acceptance of an international
recommendation during 1967[51] caused ASCII's choices for the national use
characters to seem to be de facto standards for the world, causing confusion
and incompatibility once other countries did begin to make their own
assignments to these code points.

ISO/IEC 646, like ASCII, is a 7-bit character set. It does not make any
additional codes available, so the same code points encoded different
characters in different countries. Escape codes were defined to indicate which
national variant applied to a piece of text, but they were rarely used, so it
was often impossible to know what variant to work with and, therefore, which
character a code represented, and in general, text-processing systems could
cope with only one variant anyway.

Because the bracket and brace characters of ASCII were assigned to "national
use" code points that were used for accented letters in other national
variants of ISO/IEC 646, a German, French, or Swedish, etc. programmer using
their national variant of ISO/IEC 646, rather than ASCII, had to write, and
thus read, something such as

    `ä aÄiÜ = 'Ön'; ü`

instead of

    `{ a[i] = '\n'; }`

[C trigraphs](/wiki/C_trigraph "C trigraph") were created to solve this
problem for [ANSI C](/wiki/ANSI_C "ANSI C"), although their late introduction
and inconsistent implementation in compilers limited their use. Many
programmers kept their computers on US-ASCII, so plain-text in Swedish, German
etc. (for example, in e-mail or [Usenet](/wiki/Usenet "Usenet")) contained "{,
}" and similar variants in the middle of words, something those programmers
got used to. For example, a Swedish programmer mailing another programmer
asking if they should go for lunch, could get "N{ jag har sm|rg}sar" as the
answer, which should be "Nä jag har smörgåsar" meaning "No I've got
sandwiches".

### 8-bit codes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ASCII&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: 8-bit codes")]

Main articles: [Extended ASCII](/wiki/Extended_ASCII "Extended ASCII") and
[ISO/IEC 8859](/wiki/ISO/IEC_8859 "ISO/IEC 8859")

See also: [UTF-8](/wiki/UTF-8 "UTF-8")

Eventually, as 8-, [16-](/wiki/16-bit "16-bit") and [32-bit](/wiki/32-bit
"32-bit") (and later [64-bit](/wiki/64-bit "64-bit")) computers began to
replace [18-](/wiki/18-bit "18-bit") and [36-bit](/wiki/36-bit "36-bit")
computers as the norm, it became common to use an 8-bit byte to store each
character in memory, providing an opportunity for extended, 8-bit relatives of
ASCII. In most cases these developed as true extensions of ASCII, leaving the
original character-mapping intact, but adding additional character definitions
after the first 128 (i.e., 7-bit) characters.

Encodings include [ISCII](/wiki/ISCII "ISCII") (India), [VISCII](/wiki/VISCII
"VISCII") (Vietnam). Although these encodings are sometimes referred to as
ASCII, true ASCII is defined strictly only by the ANSI standard.

Most early home computer systems developed their own 8-bit character sets
containing line-drawing and game glyphs, and often filled in some or all of
the control characters from 0 to 31 with more graphics. [Kaypro](/wiki/Kaypro
"Kaypro") [CP/M](/wiki/CP/M "CP/M") computers used the "upper" 128 characters
for the Greek alphabet.

The [PETSCII](/wiki/PETSCII "PETSCII") code [Commodore
International](/wiki/Commodore_International "Commodore International") used
for their [8-bit](/wiki/8-bit "8-bit") systems is probably unique among
post-1970 codes in being based on ASCII-1963, instead of the more common
ASCII-1967, such as found on the [ZX Spectrum](/wiki/ZX_Spectrum_character_set
"ZX Spectrum character set") computer. [Atari](/wiki/ATASCII "ATASCII") 8-bit
computers and [Galaksija](/wiki/Galaksija_\(computer\)#Character_ROM
"Galaksija \(computer\)") computers also used ASCII variants.

The IBM PC defined [code page 437](/wiki/Code_page_437 "Code page 437"), which
replaced the control characters with graphic symbols such as [smiley
faces](/wiki/Emoticon "Emoticon"), and mapped additional graphic characters to
the upper 128 positions. Operating systems such as [DOS](/wiki/DOS "DOS")
supported these code pages, and manufacturers of [IBM PCs](/wiki/IBM_PC "IBM
PC") supported them in hardware. [Digital Equipment
Corporation](/wiki/Digital_Equipment_Corporation "Digital Equipment
Corporation") developed the [Multinational Character
Set](/wiki/Multinational_Character_Set "Multinational Character Set") (DEC-
MCS) for use in the popular [VT220](/wiki/VT220 "VT220")
[terminal](/wiki/Computer_terminal "Computer terminal") as one of the first
extensions designed more for international languages than for block graphics.
The Macintosh defined [Mac OS Roman](/wiki/Mac_OS_Roman "Mac OS Roman") and
Postscript also defined a set, both of these contained both international
letters and typographic punctuation marks instead of graphics, more like
modern character sets.

The [ISO/IEC 8859](/wiki/ISO/IEC_8859 "ISO/IEC 8859") standard (derived from
the DEC-MCS) finally provided a standard that most systems copied (at least as
accurately as they copied ASCII, but with many substitutions). A popular
further extension designed by Microsoft, [Windows-1252](/wiki/Windows-1252
"Windows-1252") (often mislabeled as [ISO-8859-1](/wiki/ISO-8859-1
"ISO-8859-1")), added the typographic punctuation marks needed for traditional
text printing. ISO-8859-1, Windows-1252, and the original 7-bit ASCII were the
most common character encodings until 2008 when [UTF-8](/wiki/UTF-8 "UTF-8")
became more common.[48]

ISO/IEC 4873 introduced 32 additional control codes defined in the 80–9F
[hexadecimal](/wiki/Hexadecimal "Hexadecimal") range, as part of extending the
7-bit ASCII encoding to become an 8-bit system.[52]

### Unicode[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ASCII&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: Unicode")]

Main articles: [Unicode](/wiki/Unicode "Unicode") and [ISO/IEC
10646](/wiki/ISO/IEC_10646 "ISO/IEC 10646")

See also: [Basic Latin (Unicode block)](/wiki/Basic_Latin_\(Unicode_block\)
"Basic Latin \(Unicode block\)")

[Unicode](/wiki/Unicode "Unicode") and the ISO/IEC 10646 [Universal Character
Set](/wiki/Universal_Character_Set "Universal Character Set") (UCS) have a
much wider array of characters and their various encoding forms have begun to
supplant ISO/IEC 8859 and ASCII rapidly in many environments. While ASCII is
limited to 128 characters, Unicode and the UCS support more characters by
separating the concepts of unique identification (using [natural
numbers](/wiki/Natural_number "Natural number") called _code points_) and
encoding (to 8-, 16- or 32-bit binary formats, called [UTF-8](/wiki/UTF-8
"UTF-8"), [UTF-16](/wiki/UTF-16 "UTF-16") and [UTF-32](/wiki/UTF-32
"UTF-32")).

ASCII was incorporated into the Unicode (1991) character set as the first 128
symbols, so the 7-bit ASCII characters have the same numeric codes in both
sets. This allows [UTF-8](/wiki/UTF-8 "UTF-8") to be [backward
compatible](/wiki/Backward_compatibility "Backward compatibility") with 7-bit
ASCII, as a UTF-8 file containing only ASCII characters is identical to an
ASCII file containing the same sequence of characters. Even more importantly,
[forward compatibility](/wiki/Forward_compatibility "Forward compatibility")
is ensured as software that recognizes only 7-bit ASCII characters as special
and does not alter bytes with the highest bit set (as is often done to support
8-bit ASCII extensions such as ISO-8859-1) will preserve UTF-8 data
unchanged.[53]

## Notes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=ASCII&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section:
Notes")]

  1. ^ Jump up to: _**a**_ _**b**_ _**c**_ _**d**_ _**e**_ The 128 characters of the 7-bit ASCII character set are divided into eight 16-character groups called _sticks_ 0–7, associated with the three [most-significant bits](/wiki/Most-significant_bit "Most-significant bit").[11] Depending on the horizontal or vertical representation of the character map, _sticks_ correspond with either table rows or columns.
  2. **Jump up ^** The [Unicode](/wiki/Unicode "Unicode") characters from the area U+2400 to U+2421 reserved for representing control characters when it is necessary to print or display them rather than have them perform their intended function. Some browsers may not display these properly.
  3. **Jump up ^** [Caret notation](/wiki/Caret_notation "Caret notation") is often used to represent control characters on a terminal. On most text terminals, holding down the `[Ctrl](/wiki/Control_key "Control key")` key while typing the second character will type the control character. Sometimes the shift key is not needed, for instance `^@` may be typable with just Ctrl and 2.
  4. **Jump up ^** Character [escape sequences](/wiki/Escape_sequence "Escape sequence") in [C programming language](/wiki/C_\(programming_language\) "C \(programming language\)") and many other languages influenced by it, such as [Java](/wiki/Java_\(programming_language\) "Java \(programming language\)") and [Perl](/wiki/Perl "Perl") (though not all implementations necessarily support all escape sequences).
  5. **Jump up ^** The [Backspace](/wiki/Backspace "Backspace") character can also be entered by pressing the `← Backspace` key on some systems.
  6. ^ Jump up to: _**a**_ _**b**_ The ambiguity of [Backspace](/wiki/Backspace "Backspace") is due to early terminals designed assuming the main use of the keyboard would be to manually punch paper tape while not connected to a computer. To delete the previous character, one had to back up the paper tape punch, which for mechanical and simplicity reasons was a button on the punch itself and not the keyboard, then type the rubout character. They therefore placed a key producing rubout at the location used on typewriters for backspace. When systems used these terminals and provided command-line editing, they had to use the "rubout" code to perform a backspace, and often did not interpret the backspace character (they might echo "`^H`" for backspace). Other terminals not designed for paper tape made the key at this location produce Backspace, and systems designed for these used that character to back up. Since the delete code often produced a backspace effect, this also forced terminal manufacturers to make any `Delete` key produce something other than the Delete character.
  7. **Jump up ^** The [Tab character](/wiki/Tab_character "Tab character") can also be entered by pressing the `Tab ↹` key on most systems.
  8. **Jump up ^** The [Carriage Return](/wiki/Carriage_Return "Carriage Return") character can also be entered by pressing the `↵ Enter` or `Return` key on most systems.
  9. **Jump up ^** The `\e` [escape sequence](/wiki/Escape_sequence "Escape sequence") is not part of [ISO C](/wiki/ISO_C "ISO C") and many other language specifications. However, it is understood by several compilers, including [GCC](/wiki/GCC_\(software\) "GCC \(software\)").
  10. **Jump up ^** The [Escape character](/wiki/Escape_character "Escape character") can also be entered by pressing the `Esc` key on some systems.
  11. **Jump up ^** ^^ means `Ctrl`+`^` (pressing the "Ctrl" and [caret](/wiki/Caret "Caret") keys).
  12. **Jump up ^** The [Delete character](/wiki/Delete_character "Delete character") can sometimes be entered by pressing the `← Backspace` key on some systems.
  13. **Jump up ^** Printed out, the characters are: 
    
         !"#$%&'()*+,-./0123456789:;<=>?@ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ[\]^_`abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz{|}~
